reason:
tau(pi, psi_Q) IS NOT A WELL-DEFINED OBJECT: INHERITS CRITICAL GAP FROM NODE 1.4.

Node 1.5 claims to prove the nonvanishing of "the generalized Gauss sum tau(pi, psi_Q) arising in the K-integral." However:

(1) THE OBJECT tau(pi, psi_Q) IS NEVER DEFINED. The node provides no formula or definition for tau(pi, psi_Q). It implicitly inherits its meaning from Node 1.4, where the "K-integral" is the integral over GL_n(O) arising after Iwasawa decomposition. The precise K-integral from Node 1.4 is:

  int_{GL_n(O)} psi^{-1}(Q a_n k_{nn}) V^circ(ak) dk

This depends on the torus element a = diag(varpi^{m_1}, ..., varpi^{m_n}) and is NOT a standard mathematical object called "tau(pi, psi_Q)."

(2) NODE 1.4 HAS BEEN CRITICALLY CHALLENGED (ch-f40b2cf73eaa8ef3, major severity): the K-integral is NOT a Gauss sum for n >= 2. A Gauss sum is int chi(x) psi(x) dx where chi is a multiplicative character and psi is additive on the SAME one-dimensional group. The actual K-integral is over the n^2-dimensional group GL_n(O) with an additive twist in one variable (k_{nn}) and a Whittaker function V^circ(ak) depending on ALL entries. For n >= 2, this is a matrix coefficient integral with a partial additive twist, not a Gauss sum.

(3) THE GODEMENT-JACQUET EPSILON FACTOR IS A DIFFERENT OBJECT. The Godement-Jacquet local epsilon factor epsilon(s, pi, psi) is defined through the functional equation of the standard L-function Z(s, Phi, f) = int_{GL_n(F)} f(g) Phi(g) |det g|^s dg, where f is a matrix coefficient and Phi in S(M_n(F)). This involves integration over GL_n(F) (not GL_n(O)) with a Schwartz function on all of M_n(F) (not a single additive twist in one variable). The claim that the K-integral "follows from Godement-Jacquet" conflates two structurally different integrals.

(4) EVEN IF ONE COULD IDENTIFY THE K-INTEGRAL WITH AN EPSILON FACTOR, the relevant epsilon factor would be epsilon(s, pi, psi_Q), not tau(pi, psi_Q). The epsilon factor is always nonzero (this is a theorem), but this tells us nothing about the K-integral unless the identification is established. The node skips this identification entirely.

Without a precise definition of tau(pi, psi_Q), the claim "tau(pi, psi_Q) \!= 0" is meaningless -- one cannot prove the nonvanishing of an undefined quantity.
